item.title: license yaml format issue
item.description:
The using part of the license.txt looks weird to me. It‚Äôs an array of single-element map like this

using:
  - youtube-dl: https://github.com/rg3/youtube-dl/blob/master/LICENSE
  - kakoune: https://github.com/mawww/kakoune/blob/master/UNLICENSE
  - RDF.rb: https://github.com/ruby-rdf/rdf/blob/master/UNLICENSE

why not just use a single map like this

using:
  youtube-dl: https://github.com/rg3/youtube-dl/blob/master/LICENSE
  kakoune: https://github.com/mawww/kakoune/blob/master/UNLICENSE
  RDF.rb: https://github.com/ruby-rdf/rdf/blob/master/UNLICENSE

or an array of structered map

using:
  - name: youtube-dl
    url: https://github.com/rg3/youtube-dl/blob/master/LICENSE
  - name: kakoune
    url: https://github.com/mawww/kakoune/blob/master/UNLICENSE
  - name: RDF.rb
    url: https://github.com/ruby-rdf/rdf/blob/master/UNLICENSE

It makes the deserialise code boilerplate, for e.g in Rust I have to declare this field like

using: Option<Vec<HashMap<String, String>>>,

When using this using field, I have to iterate the vector, during which I have to iterate the single-element map! In other formats, it would be

using: Option<HashMap<String, String>>,

or

using: Option<Vec<SomeStruct>>,

item.title: Fix rendering of components that utilize `capture` in a parent view context
item.description:
In Rails, when you create a form it saves a reference to the current template object that is rendering the form. When you render a form builder helper method, like form.label inside of a child component the template object will be the original template object from where the form builder was instantiated.

This means in cases where we pass a block to a form builder helper the @output_buffer is the parent component‚Äôs output buffer. So when that buffer is overridden via .capture it‚Äôs setting the parent component‚Äôs @output_buffer to a new, temporary buffer but it doesn‚Äôt change the child component that is actually rendering‚Äôs @output_buffer. This means the block is executed in the context of the child components actual @output_buffer and immediately writes to the buffer. Since capture had nothing written to the temporary buffer, it returns the value of the block call and then inserts that into the parent component‚Äôs @output_buffer.

This resolves the issue by monkey patching ActionView::Base to support a new child_component attribute and overriding output_buffer= to set its child_components output_buffer to whatever output_buffer is set to. With that in place, when capture is called, then #output_buffer=` is called which will update the child component‚Äôs output buffer to the new temporary buffer correctly.

item.title: Moving away from TaskCluster
item.description:
TaskCluster is a CI service provided by Mozilla, and available to both Firefox development (Firefox-CI instance) and Community on Github (Community TaskCluster). It‚Äôs being widely used across some Mozilla projects, and it has its own advantages. In our case, the control over tasks, over workers for specific needs and long build time was easier to achieve working with the TaskCluster team rather than relying on other CI services.

However, this has lead to the CI code being very specific to the project, and kind of a source of frustration for non employees trying to send patches and get involved in the project ; specifically because some of the CI parts were ‚Äúhand-crafted‚Äù and triggering builds and tests requires being a ‚Äúcollaborator‚Äù on the Github project, which has other implications making it complicated to enable it easily to anyone. In the end, this creates an artificial barrier to contributing to this project, even though we happily run PRs manually, it is still frustrating for everyone. The issue https://github.com/mozilla/DeepSpeech/issues/3228 was an attempt to fix that, but we came to the conclusion it would be more beneficial for everyone to switch to some well known CI service and setup that is less intimidating. While TaskCluster is a great tool and has helped us a lot, we feel its limitations now makes it inappropriate for the project to stimulate and enable external contributions.

We would like to take this opportunity to also enable more contributors to hack and own the code related to CI, so discussion is open.

item.title: Make the set of syncable roots configurable
item.description:
We currently hard-code syncable to mean "everything under the five built-in roots". This works for @eoger‚Äôs use case (filtering out readinglist and pinned when importing bookmarks from Fennec), and it wouldn‚Äôt be much more work to make them customizable.

I imagine we‚Äôd add a method like Builder::syncable(vec![MENU_GUID, MOBILE_GUID, TOOLBAR_GUID, UNFILED_GUID]), store the list of syncable roots on the tree, and check them in Node::is_syncable.

While we‚Äôre at it, we could also generalize our special handling for tags on Desktop‚Äîthey‚Äôre part of the merged tree (so not deleted), but never uploaded. Or we can leave it and wait for tags to move to a separate table, which we already do in Rust Places. üòÅ
